issue.title: I want to update fetch-retry after v3 but it didn't work
issue.body:
Thanks for the great fetch-retry! I use it from v2.0.0
I do it using fetch-retry like this.

```
fetchRetry('https://xxxx', {
      mode: "cors",
      method: "POST",
      headers: {
         "Content-Type": "application/json;charset=utf-8",
         Accept: "application/json",
      },
      retries: 3,
      retryDelay: 800,
      body: 'xxxxxxxx',
    }),
```

It works fine up to ver:2.2.3, but ver:3.x.x or later can't communicate normally.
Communication is no response and there is no error, 
and it is not possible to update after ver3. 
What should I do, has anything changed since ver3?

Thank you very much!

issue.title: Access current URL in custom retryOn
issue.body:
Thanks for the great fetch-retry!

Is there a way to access the current URL in custom `retryOn`? Right now, I'm using `response.url` but this does not work on exceptions. Any suggestions?

issue.title: Access current URL in custom retryOn
issue.body:
Thanks for the great fetch-retry!

Is there a way to access the current URL in custom `retryOn`? Right now, I'm using `response.url` but this does not work on exceptions. Any suggestions?

comment.body: My thinking was that you could use the fetch polyfill in your application code by explicitly importing it, and wrapping it with fetch-retry, and then reserve the global fetch to the third party libraries so that they would not be affected.

issue.title: Set up Fetch-retry
issue.body:
Hi, I've tried to use fetch-retry but I don't get it. 
I've read the doc, I change my code but how am I supposed to link the API to my code ? 
I'm not a pro, it might be a stupid question, but it could be good to add it to the README.

Thanks !

issue.title: Set up Fetch-retry
issue.body:
Hi, I've tried to use fetch-retry but I don't get it. 
I've read the doc, I change my code but how am I supposed to link the API to my code ? 
I'm not a pro, it might be a stupid question, but it could be good to add it to the README.

Thanks !

comment.body:
Hello,

Not sure if I understand your question and if the problem is related to `fetch-retry` or is a general issue. 

`fetch-retry` needs to be imported first, and this is a lot easier if you use a JS bundler. Otherwise you can try out the suggestions mentioned here: https://github.com/jonbern/fetch-retry/issues/75. Once it's imported, it should be possible to use `fetch-retry` the same you would use the standard `fetch` API.

issue.title: Browser usage
issue.body: Please show us a working example for how you use fetch-retry in a browser.

comment.body:
Good that you found a solution 👍 

Most modern web apps use a JS bundler like webpack or esbuild, which makes the import easier and more streamlined. The downside is that it adds a build step, and you will need to configure the bundler.

Perhaps another alternative could be to add it directly in a `<script>` in your HTML file?

issue.title: Browser usage
issue.body: Please show us a working example for how you use fetch-retry in a browser.

issue.title: Access current URL in custom retryOn
issue.body:
Thanks for the great fetch-retry!

Is there a way to access the current URL in custom `retryOn`? Right now, I'm using `response.url` but this does not work on exceptions. Any suggestions?

comment.body:
Thanks for your feedback 👍 

Beyond using `response.url` I can't think of any ways to access the url, except perhaps by creating your own `fetch-retry` wrapper that adds your own custom logic. I think this would add a lot of complexity, and I'm not sure if it is feasible.

Instead of using the global fetch instance, would it be possible to use a fetch polyfill and wrap that with `fetch-retry`? The second code example in the link below shows how to import the polyfill at the same time as you keep the original window fetch implementation.

https://github.com/github/fetch#importing
